question: How to draw a cartoon dog? Use visual steps suitable for beginners and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin the dog cartoon outline by drawing his face. Outline the eyes using curved lines. Extend the side of one eye to form the top of the long snout or muzzle. 2. 2. At the end of the snout, draw a circle. This is the dog’s nose. Use curved lines to trace the side of the dog’s face and his forehead. Above the eyes, use curved lines to enclose the pointed eyebrows 3. 3. Draw the dog’s open, smiling mouth. Below the nose, draw a wide, curved “W” shaped line. Let it meet the nose on one side. On the other, extend the arm of the “W” all the way to the corner of the mouth. Below this, use curved lines to outline the lower jaw, the inside of the mouth, and the tongue. Contour the corner of the mouth with short lines. At the front of the snout, draw two small, triangular teeth. 4. 4. Use curved lines to enclose the rounded shapes of the dog’s ears. Then, use long curved lines to trace the top of the head, neck, and side of the body. 5. 5. Extend a long curved line below the lower jaw to form the chest. Then, use a pair of long curved lines to draw the leg. At the bottom, use overlapping curved lines to create the toes and enclose the paw. 6. 6. Contour the chest with a curved line and draw the remaining front leg. Again, use curved lines. Those at the toes should overlap. 7. 7. Draw the rear leg, bent into a sitting position, using curved lines. Again the toes should utilize overlapping curved lines. 8. 8. Draw the remaining leg of the sitting dog. Use curved lines for the back, the bent leg, and the round paw. Band the paw with short lines. 9. 9. Complete your dog cartoon outline by drawing his wagging tail. Extend two curved lines from the dog’s hip and allow them to meet at a sharp point. Beside the tail, sketch a hatch mark pattern using curved lines to simulate the motion of the tail. 10. Color your cartoon dog. We’ve shaded ours dark brown like a chocolate labrador dog.

You’ll need: pencil, eraser, black pen/marker, and optional colored pencils/markers.

Step-by-step (8 steps)

Head & muzzle
Draw a big circle for the head. Lightly add a short vertical guideline. At the bottom of the circle, sketch a small horizontal oval for the muzzle (it overlaps the circle).

Ears
Add two floppy, teardrop-like ears on the sides of the head. Their tips should hang lower than the midpoint of the head.

Nose & smile
On the muzzle, draw a small rounded triangle for the nose. From its sides, curve two short lines downward to suggest a smile. Add a wide “U” under the smile for the mouth/tongue.

Eyes & brows
Above the muzzle, draw two big ovals for eyes. Add tiny white circles for highlights and fill the pupils around them. Two small curved dashes above each eye make friendly brows.

Body shape
Under the head, draw a wide “U” shape for the chest/body. Let the head overlap the body slightly (no neck needed).

Front legs & paws
From the body, add two long “U” shapes straight down for the front legs. At the bottom, draw 3 small bumps on each paw to suggest toes.

Back leg & tail
On one side, add a “C” shaped curve for the back leg with a small oval paw peeking out. Sketch a short curved tail to one side.

Details, cleanup & style
Add a collar band and tiny tag under the head if you like. Erase extra construction lines. Trace your final outline with thicker, smooth lines. Optional spots/patches and a soft ground shadow under the paws.

Quick coloring guide (optional)

Coat: light brown or cream

Ears/patches: slightly darker brown

Nose: black; Tongue: pink

Collar: any bright color (e.g., blue)

Leave small white shines in the eyes

Proportion tip: Big head + small body + big eyes = instant cute.

question: How to draw a pumpkin? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Draw an oval or egg shape to create the first rib of the pumpkin. Then, enclose another curved shape alongside it to create a second rib. 2. 2. Continue using long curved lines to enclose rounded ribs until the pumpkin has a round, full shape. 3. 3. Draw the pumpkin's thick stem. Extend two curved lines from the top of the pumpkin. From each of these, draw a long curved line. The lines should be roughly parallel and "S" shaped. 4. 4. Use a curved line to enclose the end of the stem. Draw another curved line across it to give the tip of the stem an oval shape. Then, texture the stem with curved lines. Use additional short lines to begin enclosing the ribs visible behind the stem. 5. 5. Complete the pumpkin's ribs. Then, draw tendrils of vine terminating from the stem. Use long, curving, "S" shaped lines. 6. 6. Draw a leaf along the pumpkin vine. First, extend a curved line from the vine. This forms the leaf's stem and vein. Then, use a series of connected, curved lines to outline the body of the leaf. 7. 7. Continue to draw the body of the leaf on the opposite side of the vein. Then, draw secondary veins extending from the primary vein or midrib. 8. 8. Draw the remaining veins, and begin a second leaf. Again, use a curved line for the stem and a series of curved lines to sketch the outline of the leaf. 9. 9. Complete the leaf, erasing as necessary. Finish outlining the leaf, and draw the secondary veins. 10. Color your pumpkin. Traditionally, pumpkins are orange in color. They can also be yellow, brown, green, or white!

question: How to hand-wash delicate clothing safely? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. The tags on your clothes tell you the best ways to clean them. Read through the tag on each garment that you’re washing to see what fabric it’s made from and how to clean it properly. Keep similar fabrics together so you can wash them at the same time. Anything that can go in your machine or that has a “hand wash only” label is safe for hand-washing. If a tag says “dry clean only,” then avoid hand-washing that garment to avoid damaging it. As a quick way to check if your garments are safe to hand-wash, place a drop of water on the fabric and blot it up with a paper towel. If the color runs or bleeds, then take it to the dry cleaners. 2. Washing similar garments in the same load prevents colors from running. Sort your laundry so all the light fabrics are separated from the dark ones. Since darker colors could potentially discolor the water, wash the lightest colored clothes first and save the darker ones for last. If you have a new item of clothing that is dyed or colored, wash it separately in a different tub or basin so the color does not get on other clothing. 3. Using a stain remover beforehand makes it easier to wash out. Apply the stain remover directly over the mark on your clothes. Gently dab the stain with your fingers or brush it lightly with a new toothbrush to work the cleaner deeper into the fabric. Let the stain remover sit for about 10–15 minutes before you wash your garment. Test the stain remover in a small inconspicuous spot on your clothes before applying it directly to the stain. 4. A mild detergent meant for delicates cleans clothes more gently. Use your bathtub, sink, or large bowl depending on how many clothes you need to wash. Stick with cool or lukewarm water when you wash your clothes to prevent colors from running. Mix about 1 1 ⁄ 2 fluid ounces (44 ml) of detergent into the water until it’s completely dissolved and forms suds. [5] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Wool and fine knits: Use cold water and wool detergent to keep the fabric soft. Silk or lace: Try a no-rinse detergent to limit how much water comes in contact with the fabric. Alternatively, use mild liquid dish soap if you’re in a pinch. 5. Gently stirring the water is less damaging to clothes than scrubbing. Drop your first load of clothes into the water so they’re submerged. Then, use your hands to gently move the clothes around to wash out the dirt between the fibers. Keep agitating the water for about 2–3 minutes, or until the clothes look clean. Sweaters: Turn sweaters inside-out before washing them to clean them better. Avoid scrubbing, twisting, or rubbing your clothes together when you hand-wash them since you could stretch and damage the fabric. 6. Soaking helps lift dirt and stains deep in the fabric. Leave your clothes submerged for at least 10 minutes so the detergent has time to work through the fabric. If your clothes are really dirty or have stubborn stains, leave them in the water for up to 30 minutes so it’s even more effective. It’s normal for the water to darken as dirt lifts out of the fabric. If the water ever looks really cloudy or dirty, empty it out and refill your container. 7. A thorough rinse removes all the detergent and leftover dirt. Either empty out your container and refill it with clean water, or hold your garments underneath a running faucet. Gently squeeze your clothes as you rinse them until you don’t see any more suds coming out. Alternatively, fill a second container with clean water and transfer your clothes over to rinse them. 8. Gently squeezing your clothes prevents them from stretching. Hold your garments above the water when you squeeze them so you don’t drip. then, lay your garment flat on a towel and slowly roll the towel up to squeeze out even more water. Avoid twisting or wringing out your clothes too forcefully since you’ll stretch or damage the fabric fibers. 9. Drying your clothes flat helps them preserve their shape. While T-shirts and pants are safe to hang dry, delicate fabrics could stretch or distort. When you’re washing sweaters, silks, bras, or lingerie, spread the garments flat so they’re shaped correctly. Keep them in a well-ventilated spot and flip your clothes over after 1–2 hours so the other side can dry. Turn a fan on in the same room as your clothes to help them dry faster. Avoid putting your clothes in the dryer unless the care tag says it’s safe. Otherwise, your clothes may get damaged or shrink.
generated_text:
# Text guide: How to hand-wash delicate clothing safely

## What you’ll need

* Clean sink or basin
* Cool to lukewarm water (68–86°F / 20–30°C)
* Gentle detergent (labeled for delicates/wool/silk)
* Optional: mesh laundry bag (for lace/beads), white towels, drying rack, measuring spoon, timer

## Before you begin

* **Check the care label.** If it says “hand wash,” you’re good. If it says “dry clean only,” see the notes below.
* **Sort by color & fabric.** Wash darks separately; don’t mix heavy knits with ultra-sheer pieces.
* **Close zippers/hooks** and turn garments inside out.

## Step-by-step

1. **Fill the basin** with cool/lukewarm water.
2. **Add detergent:** about **1 tsp (5 mL) per 2 L** of water (≈½ Tbsp per gallon). Swirl to dissolve.
3. **Pre-treat spots:** dab a drop of diluted detergent on the stain; tap gently; **test in a hidden seam** first.
4. **Submerge the garment.** Gently press out air so it’s fully wet.
5. **Soak** for **10 minutes** (silk: 3–5 minutes).
6. **Agitate lightly** for **30–60 seconds**—swish and squeeze the water through the fabric. **No rubbing or wringing.**
7. **Rinse**: drain, refill with cool water, and press water through the fabric until it runs clear (repeat as needed).

   * Optional final rinse: **1 Tbsp white vinegar per gallon** to reduce residue and static (skip for garments with metal trims).
8. **Remove excess water:** lift with two hands; press against the side of the basin. **Do not twist.**
9. **Towel-roll:** lay flat on a clean towel, roll it up, and press along the roll to absorb water.
10. **Dry properly:**

    * **Knits/wool/cashmere:** lay flat on a dry towel or rack, **reshape** to measurements.
    * **Lingerie/synthetics:** hang or lay on a rack; avoid clothespin dents (use padded hangers).
    * Keep away from **direct sun or heat**; **never tumble-dry** delicates.

## Fabric-specific tips

* **Silk:** cool water, pH-neutral detergent, short soak; blot, then lay flat or hang to drip; press inside-out with a cool iron under a pressing cloth when nearly dry.
* **Wool & cashmere:** cold–cool water with wool wash; avoid temperature shock; always flat-dry.
* **Lace/tulle/beaded items:** place in a **mesh bag**, minimal agitation, flat-dry.
* **Athletic synthetics:** avoid fabric softener (it reduces wicking); hang-dry.

## Stain quick help

* **Protein (blood, milk):** cold water only; dab, don’t rub.
* **Oils/grease:** pre-treat with a small drop of detergent; let sit 5–10 min, then wash.
* **Makeup/sunscreen:** dab with detergent solution; rinse well.
* **Dye bleed:** if water tints, stop—rinse quickly and wash separately.

## When to dry-clean instead

* Structured or heavily **lined** garments, tailored suits, leather/suede, or items with heavy beading/embellishment. If unsure, test a seam first or choose professional care.

## Common mistakes to avoid

* Hot water, bleach, fabric softener on silk/wool, vigorous scrubbing, wringing/twisting, or drying in direct heat/sun.

---

question: How to clean eyeglasses without scratches or streaks? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Wash your hands before cleaning your glasses. Wash up for 20 seconds with lotion-free soap and warm water. You’ll need to make sure your hands are free of dirt, grease, and grime before cleaning your glasses. 2. Rinse your glasses with warm water. Run a gentle stream of tap water over your glasses. Rotate them to wet both sides of each lens, the frame, and earpieces. Hot water is bad for lenses, protective coatings, and the frame, so be sure to use warm water. 3. Use your fingertips to carefully lather them with dish soap. Add a small drop of lotion-free dish soap to each lens. Make gentle circular motions with your fingertips to lather the soap over both sides of your lenses, around the frame, and down each earpiece. 4. Clean the nose pads with a cotton swab or soft toothbrush. Use gentle pressure as you scrub the nose pads and the crevices between them and the frame. If you’re using a toothbrush, make sure it’s soft-bristled. Avoid grazing the lenses with the toothbrush, even if it’s soft-bristled. If there’s buildup between the lenses and the frame, use a cotton swab to loosen it. 5. Wash away soap residue. Hold the glasses under running water again to rinse away soap suds. Make sure you’ve washed away all traces of soap, as any remaining residue will cause smudges. 6. Shake off excess water and make sure your lenses are clean. Turn off the water, then give your glasses a careful shake. Check the lenses to make sure they’re clear, and wash them again if you see any smudges. 7. Dry your glasses with a microfiber cloth. Fold a clean microfiber cloth over both sides of a lens. Make soft circular motions with your fingertips to dry it, then repeat on the other lens. Wipe the nose pads, then use the cloth to dry and polish the frame and earpieces. [6] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source 8. Spray your glasses liberally with eyeglass cleaner. Spray cleaners for eyewear are available at pharmacies and eyewear retailers. If you can’t get to a sink and dish soap, spray your glasses with lots of cleaner to flush away dirt and debris. Some eyewear manufacturers and optometrists also offer free samples of spray cleaner. If you have anti-reflective (AR) glasses, make sure the cleaner you use is labelled safe for the AR coating. 9. Wipe away the cleaner with a microfiber cloth. After spraying your glasses, carefully wipe off excess cleaner. Fold the cloth over both sides of each lens, and make gentle circular motions with your fingertips to absorb the cleaner. Then use the cloth to dry the frame and earpieces. 10. Touch up your lenses with disposable eyeglass wet wipes. You can also clean your glasses with wet wipes when you’re on the go. Gently blow on them to remove dust and dirt, then gently rub them with a wet wipe using soft, circular motions. After cleaning them, dry them with a microfiber cloth. Only use wet wipes labelled for cleaning eyewear. If you have AR glasses, make sure your wipes are labelled safe for the AR coating. 11. Clean your glasses every morning and as needed. Make cleaning your glasses part of your morning routine. Check them regularly throughout the day, and touch them up as needed. Keeping your glasses clean and smudge-free will help prevent scratches. 12. Store your glasses in a hard case when you’re not wearing them. Don’t just throw your glasses in your purse or bag, and avoid placing the lenses on hard surfaces. When they’re not in use, keep them in a hard-shell case. The case should fit your glasses; if it’s too big, they might roll around and get damaged. [11] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source 13. Wash your microfiber cloths frequently. Microfiber cloths collect grease and dirt, so you should wash yours after 2 or 3 uses. Some cloths are machine washable, so check the care instructions and launder them as directed. [12] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source If your cloth isn’t machine washable, or if you’re not sure, hand wash it with dish soap, wring it out, then let it air dry. 14. Don’t wipe your glasses with your shirt, tissue, or a paper towel. Shirts, tissues, and paper towels contain fine debris that could scratch your glasses. Additionally, never wipe your glasses when they’re dry, or you’ll risk damaging them. Exhaling on your glasses and wiping them with your shirt might be convenient, but that’s a quick way to scratch up your lenses. Need help keeping your glasses clean? Check out what wikiHow users recommend on our best way to clean glasses and keep them clean? forum .

# How to Clean Eyeglasses (no scratches, no streaks)

## What you’ll need

* Clean, lotion-free hand soap
* Lukewarm (not hot) water
* A **clean microfiber cloth** (no paper towels/tissues)
* Optional: lens-safe spray cleaner; soft brush or cotton swab for nose pads/hinges

## Step-by-step

1. **Wash your hands.** Use lotion-free soap, rinse well, and dry with a lint-free towel. Oily hands = smeary lenses.
2. **Rinse the glasses first.** Hold frames under a gentle stream of **lukewarm** water to float off dust/grit (this prevents scratching).
3. **Add a tiny drop of mild dish soap.** With wet fingertips, dab a **pin-head amount** on each lens.
4. **Gently clean everything.** Using light pressure, rub both sides of the lenses, frame fronts/backs, bridge, nose pads, hinges, and temple tips for 10–15 seconds.
5. **Rinse thoroughly.** Keep water moving from the top edge of each lens down so residue doesn’t redeposit.
6. **Shake + air a moment.** Flick off excess water; let droplets slide away.
7. **Dry with microfiber only.** **Pat**, then lightly buff in small circles with a clean section of the cloth.
8. **Optional finish.** If a smudge remains, spray a lens-safe cleaner **onto the cloth (not the lens)** and buff again.

## Quick do’s & don’ts

**Do**

* Rinse before wiping—always.
* Handle by the bridge or temples so you don’t fingerprint the lenses.
* Wash your microfiber cloth regularly (no fabric softener; air-dry).

**Don’t**

* Use hot water.
* Wipe dry dust or use shirts, tissues, paper towels, or napkins.
* Use household glass cleaner, bleach, ammonia, vinegar, baking soda, or toothpaste.
* Use alcohol unless the cleaner specifically says it’s safe for your lens coatings and frames.

## Between deep cleans

* Use single-use **lens wipes** designed for eyeglasses when you’re on the go.
* For gunky nose pads/hinges, soak a minute in warm soapy water, brush gently, rinse, and dry.

## Streak & scratch troubleshooting

* **Rainbow streaks:** Soap residue—re-rinse and buff with a fresh section of cloth.
* **Persistent smears:** Cloth is dirty—wash it.
* **Fine scratches:** Stop using abrasive materials; scratches can’t be polished out—ask your optician about replacement or coatings.

question: How to tie a bowline knot securely? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Use a mnemonic to remember how to tie the knot. Think of the loop as a "rabbit's hole" and the string end coming off the loop as a "tree". Imagine the other loose end of the string, which you're holding in your right hand, is the "rabbit". The rabbit comes up the hole, runs around the tree, and goes back down the hole. Another way to remember how to make this knot is with a rhyme: "Lay the bight to make a hole Then under the back and around the pole Over the top and through the eye Clinch it tight and let it lie" 2. Hold one end of the rope in your left hand. This will be your ‘standing end’ or the end that does not move (consider this end the ‘hole’ and the ‘tree’.) Hold the other end in your right hand (this is the free end--the end of the rope that will be used to form the knot, or the ‘rabbit.’)Make a small loop with the end of the string in your left hand. This loop is the ‘hole’ the rabbit comes out of. [4] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview These instructions assume you start with an "underhand" loop, so that the free end of the string is under the intersection formed by the loop. 3. Draw the end of the string in your right hand (the rabbit) through the loop made by your left hand (the hole. ) The end should be coming towards you as it goes through the loop. Think of this as the rabbit coming out of its hole. [7] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview 4. Bring the ‘rabbit’ end around (behind) the string. This string is the part pointing upwards from the loop (the ‘tree’.) Pull the ‘rabbit’ back through the loop and down into the ‘hole’. This time the end is going away from you. [9] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview 5. Take the top loose string in your left hand. Hold the other end in your right hand and pull the ends in opposite directions to tighten the knot. [10] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview

Here’s the **text-only guide** (image above is separate, as requested):

# How to tie a bowline (securely)

**Names:** standing part = the side attached to the load; working end = free end (tail).

1. **Make the “hole”.** In the standing part, form a small overhand loop with the standing part crossing *over* the rope behind it. Keep the loop large enough to pass the working end through.

2. **Rabbit out of the hole.** Pass the working end **up through the loop**.

3. **Around the tree.** Take the working end **around the back of the standing part**, then back toward the loop.

4. **Back into the hole.** Feed the working end **down through the original loop**.

5. **Dress and set.** Hold the loop you’ve made and pull firmly on the **standing part** while snugging the “collar” around it. Adjust until the knot is compact and tidy.

6. **Safety checks (do these every time):**

* There’s a **fixed loop** that does not slip when you pull the standing part.
* A single **collar** (turn) wraps cleanly around the standing part.
* Leave a **tail ≥ 10–15 cm (4–6 in)**.

7. **Make it more secure (recommended):**

* Tie a **double overhand stopper** with the tail snug against the bowline, **or**
* Use a **Yosemite finish** (run the tail up behind the loop and back down beside the standing part, then dress snug). Either helps prevent loosening from repeated loading/unloading.

**When to use (and not):**

* Great for forming a non-slipping loop for general utility, boating, and rescue rigging by trained users.
* **Avoid for life-safety or climbing unless you’re trained** and use an appropriate backup/variation; bowlines can loosen under cyclic load or if shaken when slack.

**To untie:** Push the collar to break the set, then pull the working end—bowlines are easy to release even after heavy load.

question: Why are there different shades of stone on the Washington Monument? Provide a photo and explain.
reference_text: Construction stopped in 1854 due to lack of funds, then resumed decades later with marble from a different quarry. The mismatch created a permanent color line in the obelisk.
generated_text: Here's the explanation (text), separate from the generated photo above:The Washington Monument's color changes partway up because construction stopped for decades. Builders laid the first ~150 feet (1848–1854) using one set of marble. Funding troubles and then the Civil War halted work. When construction resumed in the late 1870s and finished in 1884, crews used marble from different quarry seams (and some from a different quarry entirely). Those stones didn't match perfectly—and over time they weathered differently—so you see a distinct horizontal "color line" and slight banding higher up.

question: Why can people stand on the Statue of Liberty? Provide a photo and explain.
reference_text: An internal spiral staircase leads to the crown, which was designed to safely accommodate small groups of visitors as a viewing platform.
generated_text:
Image (photo): (see generated image above)

Text (explanation):
People can stand inside the Statue of Liberty—on the pedestal’s observation deck and in the crown—because the monument was engineered as a habitable structure, not a solid statue.
 • Load-bearing skeleton: A robust internal iron framework (designed to carry people and stairs) holds the statue up. The green copper skin you see outside is thin and non-structural; it hangs like a curtain on the frame.
 • Platforms & stairs anchored to the frame: Metal stairways and viewing platforms are bolted to the central support and armature, so a visitor’s weight goes into the steel/iron skeleton, not the copper shell.
 • Pedestal transfers the loads: All those forces flow down into a massive granite/concrete pedestal and then into the foundation, so visitor loads are easily supported.
 • Engineered for movement & safety: The structure can flex slightly in wind, and access is controlled with rails, capacity limits, and modern safety upgrades—making the crown room and decks safe for brief occupancy.
 • Where you can’t stand: The torch is not open to the public; visitors stand on engineered platforms (pedestal decks and the crown), not on the statue’s skin.

question: How to Do Kettlebell Shrugs the Right Way? Show visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Stand holding a pair of dumbbells or kettlebells at your sides in a neutral grip. Squeeze your shoulder blades, abs, and glutes to create full-body tension. Keep your gaze straight ahead to maintain a neutral spine and stand tall to keep your shoulders back. 2. Activate your traps and raise your shoulders straight up. Do not roll your shoulders. 3. Pause for a count at the top, squeezing your traps. 4. Lower back down to the starting position slowly, taking at least two seconds.

# Text steps — Kettlebell Shrugs (Double-KB)

**Set-up**

1. **Choose weights** you can control for 8–15 smooth reps.
2. Place two kettlebells at your sides. Hinge at the hips, **neutral spine**, and deadlift them to standing.
3. **Starting stance:** feet hip-width, knees soft, arms straight at your sides, palms facing in (neutral grip), ribs down, neck long, eyes forward.

**Execution**
4) **Brace** (light core tension).
5) **Shrug straight up:** slide your shoulder blades **up** (and slightly back), bringing your shoulders toward your ears. **Do not bend your elbows** and don’t roll your shoulders.
6) **Pause** at the top for 1 second—grow tall.
7) **Lower slowly** until your shoulders are fully **down and back** (depressed). Feel a gentle stretch at the bottom.

**Tempo & Breathing**
8) Tempo: **1 second up, 2–3 seconds down.**
9) Breathing: inhale to brace, **exhale gently as you lift**, inhale on the way down.

**Reps & Sets**
10) Do **2–4 sets of 8–15 reps.** Rest 60–90 seconds. Pick a load that keeps your neck relaxed and form crisp.

**Form checkpoints (quick cues)**

* “**Ears to shoulders, not elbows to ribs.**”
* “**Arms long, wrists neutral.**”
* “**Don’t roll** the shoulders forward.”
* “**Tall neck**—no chin jutting.”
* Bells stay near your thighs; torso doesn’t sway.

**Common mistakes to avoid**

* Bending the elbows or turning it into a curl.
* Letting the ribs flare or leaning back.
* Jerking/bouncing the weight; losing control on the way down.
* Rolling the shoulders in circles.

**Variations**

* **Single-arm suitcase shrug:** one kettlebell; keep hips level—great for anti-lean stability.
* **Paused top shrug:** 2–3-sec hold at the top.
* **Heavier, low-rep sets (6–10)** once form is solid.

**Warm-up idea (quick)**

* 30–60s light band pull-apart holds + 10 scapular wall slides, then a light set of shrugs to groove the motion.

> Tip: If you feel neck strain, reduce load, shorten range, and emphasize “shoulders down” between reps. Discomfort in the joint = stop and reassess.

question: How to Do a Cartwheel? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Picture an imaginary line extending straight in front of you. Use this line as a guide while you perform your cartwheel. You can even use painter’s tape to create a real line across a carpet or a mat . Make this line several feet long. Try to stay on the line, as if the line is a balance beam. As you focus on the line, be sure to keep your form in mind, too. Make sure the area around your line is free and clear. Avoid practicing cartwheels near walls or pieces of furniture that you might run into. Injuries occur when you bump into something hard. Stretch your arms and legs before practicing a cartwheel. This helps to stretch out your muscles and reduces the risk of injury. 2. Lunge forward with your lead leg and raise your arms. Slightly bend your front leg at the knee and keep your back leg straight. Keep both feet pointing forward parallel to your imaginary line. Hold your arms straight up by your ears. A common mistake is to start a cartwheel while facing sideways. Make sure you’re facing forwards as you prepare and start for your cartwheel. That is the correct way. Either leg can be your lead leg. Sometimes, however, it's more comfortable to use one leg instead of the other—you can try to figure out which one by doing a series of handstands, some starting with your right leg in front, others with your left. Whichever leading leg feels more natural is the one you should use for your cartwheel.You can determine your leading by watching which leg in splits feels more comfortable. 3. Lower your arms towards the ground while raising your back leg. Keep your arms straight by your ears as you lower them down to bring your head and torso down as well. Only lower your arms about halfway to the ground. Bring your back leg up while keeping it straight so your body forms a “T” shape. This step requires balance. You may need to drop your leg several times before you find a balanced position you can hold. Don’t worry if you’re having trouble balancing. Once you get the hang of the cartwheel, you won’t have to hold this position for very long since it will all become one continuous and natural movement. 4. Place your hands on the mat as you turn your body sideways. Put down the arm on the same side of your body as your lead leg first. Then put your other arm down so they're spread about shoulder width apart, similar to the way they would be positioned for a handstand. Place both hands along the imaginary line. Think "hand hand feet" to help you process the cartwheel. For example, if you lunged with your right leg, place your right hand down first, then your left hand. Keep the fingers of each hand pointing away from your head. 5. Push off on your front leg, then bring your legs up in a V shape. Straighten your front leg as you push so your legs end up in the air, pointing straight upwards. Balance your weight on your arms with your hands shoulder-width apart on either side of your head. Keep your head and torso upside down and positioned directly over your arms. Use your shoulders and core for support. You won’t hold this position for long. Cartwheels should be performed in one fluid motion. Make sure to keep your legs straight the whole time. If you are a beginner, then you may want to practice more. 6. Lower your lead leg as you lift the first hand you put down off the mat. To complete the cartwheel, put your leading leg down first along your imaginary line. The first hand you placed on the mat will lift up naturally as your foot comes down. Bring your arm up by your ear to finish the cartwheel. Your weight should start to shift onto your legs. Keep your head and torso roughly parallel to the mat. 7. Bring your other leg down while lifting your other hand off the mat. Your other leg will follow the first as it comes down. Make sure to place your back foot behind your leading foot along the same imaginary line so both feet point back in the direction you came from. Your second hand will lift naturally off the mat, following the first hand. At this point, both your head and torso should be right side up, centered over your legs. A common mistake while cartwheeling is leaving your hands on the ground for too long. Make sure that your arms stay straight and by your ears as your chest and head come up at the end of the cartwheel. 8. Land in a lunge facing in the opposite direction. Position yourself so your original back leg is in front and slightly bent, while your original leading leg is behind you and straight, just like a lunge. Keep both feet pointing in the direction you came from. Make sure your arms are straight and pointing upwards, next to your ears. Position your torso in the same direction your feet are pointing.

# How to Do a Cartwheel (6 Steps)

> This guide describes a **right-handed cartwheel** (start with the **right foot forward**, plant **right hand, then left**, land **left foot, then right**). Reverse left/right if you’re left-handed.

## 1) Start in a Lunge (Right Foot Forward)

* Right foot in front, left foot behind on a straight “cartwheel line.”
* Front knee bent, back leg straight.
* Arms straight by your ears; torso tall, eyes forward.

## 2) Reach & Kick

* Lean over the front leg and **reach your right hand** toward the floor on the line.
* **Kick the left leg** powerfully up to start the rotation.
* Keep arms straight, ribs in, core tight.

## 3) Place Hands (Right → Left)

* **Right hand** plants first on the line; fingers slightly turned inward.
* **Left hand** plants shoulder-width from the right, forming a half-circle print.
* Head neutral (look past your hands); elbows locked.

## 4) Inverted Split (Upside Down)

* Stack **hips over shoulders**; body turns sideways.
* Legs make a wide **split overhead**; knees straight, toes pointed.
* Push tall through the shoulders to keep space between ears and shoulders.

## 5) Feet Down (Left → Right)

* The **left (kicking) foot** reaches for and **lands first** on the line.
* The **right foot** follows to absorb into a lunge.
* Keep chest lifted; don’t collapse.

## 6) Finish Lunge (Opposite Direction)

* End in a lunge facing the opposite way with **left foot forward**.
* Arms finish by your ears; hold still for control.

---

### Quick Cues

* “**Lunge → Reach → Kick → Hands → Split → Feet → Finish**.”
* Think: **Right foot, right hand, left hand, left foot, right foot**.

### Safety & Practice Tips

* Warm up wrists, shoulders, and hamstrings.
* Practice on a mat or grass with a clear, open lane.
* Use a chalk/tape **line** to guide hands/feet.
* If new to cartwheels, work with a **coach or spotter**.

question:
I am preparing a figure for my paper to illustrate the following framework:
This diagram presents the pipeline of the proposed **StyleMaster**, which performs video stylization guided by a style image and a textual description.

The framework is composed of the following major components:

1. **Input & Output**:
   - The input is a raw video and a style image (e.g., Van Gogh painting).
   - The output is a stylized video with artistic consistency.

2. **Style Extraction**:
   - The style image is encoded using a **CLIP image encoder** to extract patch-level features and image embeddings.
   - Patches with lower similarity to the accompanying text prompt (e.g., "A lone penguin walks on a sandy beach at sunset.") are selected for style representation.
   - A local selection module (Q-Former) refines these patches.
   - A **global projection module** transforms them into global style tokens using contrastive learning, enhanced with specially constructed data pairs.

3. **Contrastive Dataset Construction**:
   - Positive pairs are created by rearranging anchor images.
   - Negative samples are synthesized via **model illusion** from arbitrary text-to-image models.

4. **Stylization Network (DiT Block)**:
   - A spatial-temporal diffusion transformer (DiT) applies multiple blocks of self-attention and cross-attention.
   - Style and text features are injected via decoupled cross-attention modules.
   - A motion adapter handles temporal consistency.

5. **Gray Tile ControlNet**:
   - Ensures better content preservation and stylization control.

Please generate:
 1. A visual diagram that clearly shows the pipeline from video and style image input to stylized video output.
 2. A separate caption summarizing the figure. Please provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: The pipeline of our proposed StyleMaster. We first obtain patch features and image embedding of the style image from CLIP, then we select the patches sharing less similarity with text prompt as texture guidance, and use a global projection module to transform it into global style descriptions. The global projection module is trained with a contrastive dataset constructed by model illusion through contrastive learning. The style information is then injected into the model through the decoupled cross-attention. The motion adapter and gray tile ControlNet are used to enhance dynamic quality and enable content control respectively.
generated_text: StyleMaster pipeline. A CLIP-based style extractor selects low text-aligned patches from the reference style image, refines them with a Q-Former, and projects them via contrastive learning into global style tokens trained with positives (rearranged anchors) and negatives (model-illusion samples). A spatial–temporal DiT injects text and style through decoupled cross-attention and a motion adapter for temporal consistency. A Gray Tile ControlNet conditions the diffusion to preserve content and control stylization, producing a coherent stylized video.

question: What is a covalent bond and how does it form in ammonia (NH₃)? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram depicts covalent bonds in the ammonia compound. A covalent bond is a chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms. Ammonia is a compound of nitrogen and hydrogen with the formula NH₃. It has 3 hydrogen atoms and 1 nitrogen atom. The nitrogen atom has 5 outer electrons, and the hydrogen atom has 1 electron. The nitrogen atom shares 2 electrons with each hydrogen atom, one provided by the nitrogen atom and the other provided by the hydrogen atom.

# Written explanation

A **covalent bond** is a chemical bond formed when two atoms **share a pair of electrons**. The shared pair is attracted by both nuclei, which holds the atoms together. Each atom “counts” both electrons toward a stable valence (an octet for most atoms, a duet for hydrogen).

**How it forms in ammonia (NH₃):**

* **Nitrogen (N)** has **5 valence electrons**. Three are unpaired and available for bonding; the remaining two make **one lone pair**.
* **Each hydrogen (H)** has **1 valence electron** and needs one more to reach a duet.
* Nitrogen shares one electron with each of three hydrogens, creating **three N–H covalent (σ) bonds**—three shared pairs.
* After bonding, **N achieves an octet** (3 shared pairs = 6 electrons + its lone pair = 8) and **each H achieves a duet**.
* The molecule adopts **sp³** electron geometry with a **trigonal pyramidal shape**; the **H–N–H angle is ~107°** (slightly less than 109.5° because the lone pair repels bonding pairs more strongly).
* Each **N–H bond is polar covalent** (electrons are drawn a bit toward N), making NH₃ a polar molecule.

question: How does the alignment of the Sun and Moon cause a spring tide? Provide an image and brief explanation.
reference_text: Spring tides occur after new or full moons when Sun, Moon, and Earth are aligned. The combined gravitational force creates the largest tidal ranges.

**Text (brief explanation):**
A **spring tide** happens during the **new moon** and **full moon** when the **Sun, Moon, and Earth line up** (syzygy). In this alignment, the Sun’s tidal pull **adds to** the Moon’s stronger tidal pull, so the ocean’s tidal bulges line up along the Sun–Moon–Earth line. The result is a **larger tidal range**: **higher high tides** and **lower low tides** than average, occurring about **every two weeks**. Local coastline shape, depth, and weather can modify the exact heights.

question: What happens during alpha decay? Can you explain using the diagram?
reference_text: Alpha decay is when a heavy atom like Radium loses an alpha particle (2 protons and 2 neutrons), forming a new, lighter atom like Radon. The diagram shows how the mass and atomic number change.
generated_text:
# Text explanation (paired with the diagram above)

Alpha decay is when a heavy, unstable nucleus ejects an **alpha particle**—a tightly bound cluster of **2 protons + 2 neutrons** (a (^{4}_{2}\mathrm{He}) nucleus). This turns the original (parent) nucleus into a new (daughter) element.

**What the diagram shows:**

1. **Alpha cluster inside the parent.**
   For brief moments, a (2p+2n) cluster exists inside the nucleus.

2. **Quantum tunneling through the barrier.**
   The alpha is trapped by the strong nuclear force but pushed outward by Coulomb repulsion from the other protons. Its energy is **below** the top of the barrier, yet it can still escape by *tunneling* (inset potential curve).

3. **Transformation (notation).**
   [
   ^A_Z X ;\rightarrow; ^{A-4}_{Z-2} Y ;+; ^4_2\mathrm{He} ;+; Q
   ]

   * **Mass number (A)** drops by 4.
   * **Atomic number (Z)** drops by 2 (element changes).
   * (Q) is the released energy from the small mass difference.

4. **Energy and momentum sharing.**
   The (Q)-value appears mainly as the **kinetic energy of the alpha**, with a smaller **recoil** of the daughter nucleus; momenta are equal and opposite.

5. **Takeaway.**
   Alpha decay reduces a heavy nucleus to a slightly lighter one, emitting a helium-4 nucleus and energy; the escape happens via **quantum tunneling**, not by climbing over the barrier.

If you’d like, I can generate a second version of the diagram with a specific real example (e.g., (^{238}\mathrm{U}\rightarrow{}^{234}\mathrm{Th}+\alpha)) and labeled numbers that match these steps exactly.

Each neuron in this layer is connected only to a local spatial region in the input volume, but spans the full depth (i.e. all color channels). There are multiple neurons (5 in this example) along the depth, each using a different filter. These neurons share the same receptive field but not weights. Alright, here’s how a CNN layer processes an image:

1. **Input Image**: A CNN starts with an image, which is represented as a matrix of pixel values. Each pixel has color channels (e.g., RGB).

2. **Convolution Operation**: In a CNN layer, a small matrix called a filter (or kernel) slides over the image. This filter performs a dot product between itself and the section of the image it’s currently covering. It moves across the entire image, extracting features like edges, textures, or patterns.

3. **Neurons**: Each neuron in the CNN layer corresponds to one region of the image processed by the filter. After the filter slides over an area of the image, the result of the convolution is passed to a neuron, which computes the weighted sum of the values and then applies an activation function (like ReLU).

4. **Activation**: After the neuron processes the result, it passes the output to the next layer or saves it for further processing.

question: I'm studying the Flamingo model architecture, specifically the Gated XATTN-DENSE layer. Can you explain how this layer works and its components?
reference_text: The Gated XATTN-DENSE layer in Flamingo is a crucial component that combines gated cross-attention and gated feed-forward layers to process vision and language inputs. It performs self-attention on the language input and cross-attention with the vision input. The layer includes gating parameters, alpha_xattn and alpha_dense, to control the contribution of the attention and feed-forward operations. The layer outputs language features enhanced with visual information, allowing the model to process multimodal data efficiently.
generated_text:
Text (separate from the image):

# What is the Gated XATTN-DENSE layer?

In Flamingo, this is the multimodal **adapter** inserted into a frozen language model (LM) so token representations can **attend to visual latents** while keeping the LM’s original behavior largely intact. It’s a two-part block:

1. a **gated cross-attention (XATTN)** sublayer, and
2. a **gated feed-forward (“DENSE”/MLP)** sublayer, each wrapped with pre-LayerNorm and residual connections.

---

## Inputs

* **Text hidden states** (H \in \mathbb{R^{T\times d}}): current LM token embeddings.
* **Visual latents** (Z \in \mathbb{R^{M\times d_v}}): a fixed set of tokens produced by the Perceiver Resampler from one or more images/video frames.
* (Learned) **gating projections** that turn each token’s state into an element-wise gate.

---

## Step-by-step flow

### 1) Gated Cross-Attention (XATTN)

* **Pre-norm:** (\tilde H = \mathrm{LN}(H)).
* **Cross-attention:** queries (Q) come from (\tilde H); keys/values (K,V) come from (Z).
  [
  A=\mathrm{MHA}(\tilde H W_Q,\; ZW_K,\; ZW_V)
    ]
* **Gate the visual update:** compute a token-wise, channel-wise gate
  [
  g_x=\sigma(\tilde H W_{gx}+b_{gx})\in\mathbb{R^{T\times d}},
    ]
  then modulate the cross-attn output and add residually: [
  H^{(1)}=H + g_x \odot A.
    ]
  The gate lets the layer learn **how much** each token should trust vision, often starting near “closed” so initial behavior matches the base LM.

### 2) Gated DENSE (position-wise MLP)

* **Pre-norm:** (\hat H=\mathrm{LN}(H^{(1)})).
* **MLP/Dense:** (F=\phi(\hat H W_1 + b_1) W_2 + b_2) (with a standard nonlinearity (\phi), e.g., GELU).
* **Gate the MLP update:**
  [
  g_d=\sigma(\hat H W_{gd}+b_{gd}),\qquad
  H_{\text{out}}=H^{(1)} + g_d \odot F.
    ]

---

## Why the gating?

* **Stability with frozen backbones:** The LM (and typically the vision encoder) can remain frozen; new parameters are in the XATTN/DENSE paths and their gates. Gating prevents overwhelming the LM with visual signals early in training and enables smooth **modality balancing**.
* **Token-specific control:** Gates are computed **per token** and **per channel**, so some words (e.g., nouns near image mentions) can open the visual pathway more than others.
* **Regularization by design:** With gates near zero, the block reduces to an identity map, which curbs overfitting and preserves strong language priors.

---

## Placement in Flamingo

These Gated XATTN-DENSE blocks are **interleaved at several points** inside the LM stack. During inference on interleaved image–text streams, each text segment can query the relevant **cached** visual latents via the XATTN, while standard self-attention continues to handle language context.

---

## Summary of components

* **LayerNorm (pre-norm)** before each sublayer
* **Multi-Head Cross-Attention** (Q from text, K/V from visual latents)
* **Learned sigmoid gates** (g_x, g_d) (element-wise modulation)
* **Position-wise MLP (“DENSE”)**
* **Residual connections** after both sublayers

If you’d like, I can annotate the diagram with your preferred symbols (e.g., different gate shapes, head counts, or exact tensor sizes) and export it as SVG or PDF.

question: How to scan a QR code on iPhone? Show easy visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Open the Photos app. In most cases, you'll need the screenshot saved to your device in order to use the QR code. Open the screenshot. Locate the screenshot in your gallery and tap it. 3. Long-press the QR code. To long-press, tap and hold the code. A pop-up menu will open. You'll see several options, depending on the link. 4. Tap Open in Safari . If you have another preferred browser, you can select it. question: How to Turn Off Your iPhone? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Press and hold a volume button and the right side button simultaneously. It doesn't matter which volume button you press. After holding down these buttons for a few seconds, a slider will appear on the screen. If you don't hold down long enough, you might take a screenshot . 2. Drag the slider to the right. This powers off your iPhone. It can take up to 30 seconds for your iPhone to power down. 3. Press and hold the right side button to turn the iPhone back on. You can lift your finger from the button once the Apple logo appears. You may need to wait a few moments until you can use your iPhone . If your device is unresponsive, you can perform a hard reset .
